{{Infobox CBB Team |name = Oregon State Beavers |current = 2011â12 Oregon State Beavers men's basketball team |logo = Oregon State Beavers logo.png |logo_size = 150 |university = Oregon State University |conference = Pacific-12 Conference |conference_short = Pac-12 |city = Corvallis |stateabb = OR |state = Oregon |coach = [[Craig Robinson (basketball)|Craig Robinson]] |tenure = 3rd |arena = [[Gill Coliseum]] |capacity = 10,400 |nickname = [[Oregon State Beavers|Beavers]] |studentsection = Beaver Dam |color1 = Black |color2 = Orange |hex1 = 000000 |hex2 = e55302 |NCAAfinalfour = 1949, 1963 |NCAAeliteeight = 1949, 1963, 1955, 1962, 1966, 1982 |NCAAsweetsixteen = 1949, 1963, 1955, 1962, 1966, 1975, 1982 |NCAAtourneys = 1947, 1949, 1955, 1962, 1963, 1964, 1966, 1975, 1980, 1981, 1982, 1984, 1985, 1988, 1989, 1990 |conference_tournament = |conference_season = 1909, 1912, 1916, 1918, 1925, 1933, 1935, 1940, 1942, 1947, 1949, 1954, 1955, 1958, 1966, 1980, 1981, 1982, 1984, 1990 |h_body=FFFFF |h_pattern_b=_thinorangesides |h_shorts=FFFFF |h_pattern_s=_orangesides |a_body=000000 |a_pattern_b=_thinorangesides |a_shorts=000000 |a_pattern_s=_orangesides |3_body=CC5500 |3_pattern_b=_thinblacksides |3_shorts=CC5500 |3_pattern_s=_blacksides }} [[File:Craig robinson osu.jpg|thumb|300px|Coach Robinson in his introductory press conference as head coach]] [[File:Gill Coliseum.jpg|thumb|300px|Gill Coliseum pre-game]] The '''Oregon State Beavers men's basketball''' program, established in 1901, is the [[college basketball|intercollegiate men's basketball]] program of the [[Oregon State University]] [[Oregon State Beavers|Beavers]]. The program is classified in the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]'s [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]], and the team competes in the [[Pacific-12 Conference]]. The team is coached by [[Craig Robinson (basketball)|Craig Robinson]]. OSU is the 15th winningest program of all time as of the end of the 2008-09 season with a record of 1,594 wins and 1,180 losses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncaa.org/wps/ncaa?ContentID=1014|title=NCAA Men's Basketball Statistics|accessdate=2008-12-19}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The team plays home games in [[Gill Coliseum]].
==NCAA record{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}}== Oregon State holds several NCAA basketball records:
'''Individual Records''' *Field Goal Percentage (Single season) **'''1st''' â 74.6% â [[Steve Johnson (basketball)|Steve Johnson]], 1981 (235 of 315) **'''4th''' â 71.0% â [[Steve Johnson (basketball)|Steve Johnson]], 1980 (211 of 297) *Field Goal Percentage (Career, min. 400 made and 4 made per game) **'''1st''' â 67.8% â [[Steve Johnson (basketball)|Steve Johnson]], 1976â81 (828 of 1,222) *Field Goal Percentage (Single game, min. 12 field goals made) **'''1st (tie)''' â 100% [[Steve Johnson (basketball)|Steve Johnson]] vs. Hawaii-Hilo (13 of 13), Dec. 5, 1979 *Total Rebounds (Single game) **'''15th (tie)''' â 36 â [[Swede Halbrook]] vs. Idaho, Feb. 15, 1955 *Assists (Career) **'''11th''' â 939 â [[Gary Payton]], 1987â1990 *Average Assists Per Game (Career, min. 550 assists) **'''9th''' â 7.82 â [[Gary Payton]], 1987â1990 *Steals (Career) **'''18th (tie)''' â 321 â [[Gary Payton]], 1987â1990 '''Top Season Performances by Class''' *Senior â Field Goal Percentage **'''1st''' â 74.6% â [[Steve Johnson (basketball)|Steve Johnson]], 1981 (235 of 315) *Junior â Field Goal Percentage **'''1st''' â 71.0% â [[Steve Johnson (basketball)|Steve Johnson]], 1980 (211 of 297) '''Team Records''' *Free-Throw Percentage (Single game, min. 30 free throws made) **'''12th (tie)''' â 30â31 vs. Memphis, Dec. 19, 1990 *Steals (Single game) *'''19th (tie)''' â 27 vs. Hawaii-Loa, Dec. 22, 1985 *Field Goal Percentage (Season) **'''3rd''' â 56.4% â 1981 **'''25th (tie)''' â 54.4% â 1980 *All-Time Victories (Min. 25 years in Division I) **'''13th''' â 1,546 games *Games played vs. Single Opponent **'''1st''' â 332 vs. Oregon **'''2nd''' â 275 vs. Washington **'''4th''' 270 vs. Washington State *Victories vs. Single Opponent **'''1st''' â 182 vs. Oregon **'''6th''' 159 vs. Washington State
<!-- Removing this for now, until it is filled out--> ==Season-by-season results== {{CBB Yearly Record Start | type = team | conference = | postseason = | poll = both}} {{CBB Yearly Record End | overall = | poll = | polltype= | polltype2 = }}
==Coaches== The Oregon State men's basketball team has had 20 head coaches and one interim head coach. Both [[Slats Gill]] and [[Ralph Miller]] are members of the [[Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame]]. The current coach, Craig Robinson, was hired by OSU in 2008 out of [[Brown University]], where Robinson had just coached the [[Brown Bears|Bears]] to a school record 19 wins.<ref name="Robinson">{{cite web|url=http://www.osubeavers.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/040808aad.html|title=Craig Robinson Era Begins at Oregon State|accessdate=2008-12-21}}</ref> Robinson is the brother of United States first lady [[Michelle Obama]], and the brother-in-law to United States [[President]] [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.projo.com/sports/billreynolds/sp_bkc_rencol10_02-10-08_RR8V36O_v13.32c51e2.html | title=Heâs much more than Obamaâs brother-in-law | author=Reynolds, Bill | publisher=''[[The Providence Journal]]'' | date=2008-02-14 | accessdate=2008-11-09}}</ref> The longest tenured coach is Slats Gill, who was the coach for 36 seasons, winning 599 games in the process.

==Rivalries== '''Oregon Ducks''' — The [[Civil War (college rivalry)|Civil War]] is Oregon State's main rivalry.
'''Washington Huskies''' — [[The Dog Fight]] is one of Oregon State's lesser known rivalry games.
'''Washington State Cougars''' — The Cougars and Beavers are longtime Pac 12 (and regional) rivals.
==Current roster== The team currently has 15 players on the roster.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.osubeavers.com/sports/m-baskbl/mtt/orst-m-baskbl-mtt.htmlDB_OEM_ID=4700&KEY=&SPID=1954&SPSID=24842|title=Men's Basketball - 2000-10 Roster & Bios|accessdate=2017-12-12}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> <!-- correct link at http://www.osubeavers.com/sports/m-baskbl/mtt/orst-m-baskbl-mtt.html --> {{Bt start}} {{Bt player|no=0|nat=USA|pos=F|year=Jr|name=Kevin McShane}} {{Bt player|no=1|nat=USA|pos=G|year=So|name=Jared Cunningham}} {{Bt player|no=3|nat=USA|pos=G|year=Fr|name=Ahmad Starks}} {{Bt player|no=4|nat=USA|pos=F|year=Fr|name=Chris Brown}} {{Bt player|no=11|nat=USA|pos=F|year=So|name=Joe Burton}} {{Bt player|no=12|nat=Australia|pos=C|year=So|name=Angus Brandt}} {{Bt player|no=13|nat=Australia|pos=F|year=Fr|name=Rhys Murphy}} {{Bt player|no=15|nat=USA|pos=G|year=Fr|name=Eric Moreland}} {{Bt player|no=22|nat=USA|pos=G|year=Sr|name=Calvin Haynes}} {{Bt player|no=24|nat=USA|pos=F|year=Sr|name=Omari Johnson}} {{Bt player|no=30|nat=USA|pos=F|year=Sr|name=Daniel Deane}} {{Bt player|no=34|nat=USA|pos=G|year=Sr|name=Lathen Wallace}} {{Bt player|no=41|nat=USA|pos=C|year=Fr|name=Daniel Jones}} {{Bt player|no=44|nat=USA|pos=F|year=Fr|name=Devon Collier}} {{Bt player|no=55|nat=USA|pos=G|year=Fr|name=Roberto Nelson}} {{Bt end}}
==Notable players== Oregon State has had 75 all-conference and 32 [[All-America]] selections, five Pac-10 Players of the Year, 42 players selected in the [[NBA Draft]], and 24 players that have gone on to play in the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]].<ref name="Robinson" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.databasebasketball.com/players/bycollege.htm?sch=Oregon+State+University|title=NBA/ABA Players who attended Oregon State University|accessdate=2017-12-12}}</ref> Additionally, OSU basketball alumni have 4 gold medals at the [[Olympic Games|Olympics]], including one by [[Lew Beck (basketball)|Lew Beck]], who never played in the NBA. A total of 7 players have won 11 NBA titles, including three by [[A. C. Green]], two by [[Brent Barry]], two by [[Mel Counts]], and one each by [[Red Rocha]], [[Dave Gambee]], [[Lonnie Shelton]], and [[Gary Payton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.osubeavers.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/091907aab.html|title=Barry Wins Another NBA Title|accessdate=2008-12-21}}</ref>
The players who have gone on to play in the NBA are: *[[Brent Barry]] *[[Vic Bartolome]] *[[Corey Benjamin]] *[[Ricky Berry]] *[[Ray Blume]] *[[Freddie Boyd]] *[[Jay Carty]] *[[Lester Conner]] *[[Mel Counts]] *[[Gary Freeman (basketball)|Gary Freeman]] *[[Dave Gambee]] *[[A. C. Green]] *[[Swede Halbrook]] *[[Scott Haskin]] *[[Jim Jarvis]] *[[Steve Johnson (basketball)|Steve Johnson]] *[[John Mandic]] *[[JosÃ© Ortiz]] *[[Gary Payton]] *[[Loy Petersen]] *[[Mark Radford]] *[[Red Rocha]] *[[Lonnie Shelton]] *[[Charlie Sitton]]
==Notable Seasons== ===Orange Express=== [[File:Orange express.jpg|thumb|alt=Oregon State's 1980-81 basketball team known as the Orange Express.|The '''Orange Express''' with [[Steve Johnson (basketball)|Steve Johnson]] as #33.]] The 1980-1981 Oregon State men's basketball season was arguably one of the best and ironically most upsetting basketball seasons in Oregon State history. The team was referred to as the '''Orange Express''' and was led by Beaver legendary coach [[Ralph Miller]].<ref name="Orange Express">{{cite web|url=http://alumni.oregonstate.edu/eclips/history/bballhistory01.html|title=OSU Sports History Minute|accessdate=2010-12-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://oregonsportshall.org/osb81.html|title=1980-81 OSU Basketball Team|accessdate=2010-12-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.osualum.com/s/359/file_lib/1/18/200804_Orange_Distress_633441207175875741.pdf|title=Orange Distress|accessdate=2010-12-22}}</ref> The Orange Express season was Beaver great, [[Steve Johnson (basketball)|Steve Johnson's]], last year at OSU. This season would be the first time in OSU history that the Beavers would win at [[Pauley Pavilion|UCLA]]. The Orange Express spent a school record 25 weeks as #1 in the polls while finishing with a 26-2 record. At 26-1 the team would go into the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA tournament]] as a number one seed and were upset by number eight seed [[Kansas State Wildcats|Kansas State]] 50-48. Miller was awarded [[1980â81_NCAA_Division_I_men's_basketball_season#Major_coach_of_the_year_awards|UPI]] and [[1980â81_NCAA_Division_I_men's_basketball_season#Major_coach_of_the_year_awards|AP Coach of the Year]] honors and Steve Johnson would receive [[1981 NCAA Men's Basketball All-Americans|All-American]] honors.<ref name="Orange Express" /> Throughout 1980-83 OSU held a 77-11 record which at the time was only bested by [[DePaul Blue Demons men's basketball|DePaul's]] 79-6 record. This record would include a 35-1 record at [[Gill Coliseum]] including a school best 24 wins in a row.<ref name="Orange Express" />
==Conferences== {| class="wikitable" !Years !Conference |- |1901â1908 || Independent |- |1908â1915 || Northwest Conference (NWC) |- |1915â1959 || [[Pacific Coast Conference|Pacific Coast Conference (PCC)]] |- |1959â1964|| Independent |- |1964â1968|| [[Pacific-12 Conference#AAWU (Big Five and Big Six)|Athletic Association of Western Universities (AAWU)]] |- |1968â1978 || [[Pacific-12 Conference#Pacific-8|Pacific-8 Conference]] |- |1978â2011 || [[Pacific-12 Conference#Pacific-10|Pacific-10 Conference]] |- |2011âpresent || [[Pacific-12 Conference]] |}
==Post-Season History{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}}== '''NCAA Tournament''' (16 appearances)
''1947'': lost to Oklahoma 56-54, beat Wyoming 63-46 (West Regional consolation)
''1949'': beat Arkansas 56-38, lost to Oklahoma State 55-30 (West Regional final)
''1955'': beat Seattle 83-71, lost to San Francisco 57-56 (West Regional final)
''1962'': beat Seattle 69-65 OT, beat Pepperdine 69-67, lost to UCLA 88-69 (West Regional final)
''1963'': beat Seattle 70-66, beat San Francisco 65-61, beat Arizona State 83-65, lost to Cincinnati 80-46, lost to Duke 85-63 (Final Four third place game)
''1964'': lost to Seattle 61-57 (West Regional first round)
''1966'': beat Houston 63-60, lost to Utah 70-64 (West Regional final)
''1975'': beat Middle Tennessee State 78-67, lost to Indiana 81-71, lost to Central Michigan 88-87 (Midwest Regional consolation)
''1980'': (2), lost to (10) Lamar 81-77 (West Regional second round)
''1981'': (1), lost to (8) Kansas State 50-48 (West Regional second round)
''1982'': (2), beat (7) Pepperdine 70-51, beat (3) Idaho 60-42, lost to (1) Georgetown 69-45 (West Regional final)
''1984'': (6), lost to (11) West Virginia 64-62 (Mideast Regional first round)
''1985'': (10), lost to (7) Notre Dame 79-70 (Southeast Regional first round)
''1988'': (12), lost to (5) Louisville 70-61 (Southeast Regional first round)
''1989'': (6), lost to (11) Evansville 94-90 OT (West Regional first round)
''1990'': (5), lost to (12) Ball State 54-53 (West Regional first round)<ref>http://www.oregonlive.com/collegebasketball/index.ssf/2008/03/postseason_history.html</ref>
'''National Invitational Tournament''' (4 appearances)
''1979'': lost to Nevada 61-62 (1st Round)
''1983'': beat Idaho 77-59, beat New Orleans 88-71, lost to Fresno State 67-76 (Quarterfinal)
''1987'': beat New Mexico 85-82, lost to California 62-65 (2nd Round)
''2005'': lost to Cal State Fullerton 83-85 (opening round)
'''College Basketball Invitational''' (2 appearances, 1 Championship)
''2009'': beat Houston 49-45, beat Vermont 71-70 OT, beat Stanford 65-62 OT, beat UTEP 75-69, lost to UTEP 63-70, beat UTEP 81-73 (Tournament Champions)
''2010'': lost to Boston University 78-96 (first round)
